what we call a region which is really a concept of a jurisdictional boundary we've talked about some of that in the security presentations the idea is if
you put data in the region it's going to stay in the region it's not going to leak to other regions um you can proactively move data from one region to
another but it's not something that we'll do um and what we do is we give customers the ability to run
applications across we're really data center so this idea of availability zones so the idea of availability zones
is really a fault separation concept it's it's just the simple idea that we have a whole collection of data centers
um and what we can do is by virtue of the scale we're running at we can have different Power providers going into
each each set of data centers and so what we can do is say if uh if you if you create availability Zone a and

provider for each they're on different flood planes typically they have Geographic separation requirements
Network diversity so those are all the things that we put into um in terms of the availability zones and the

here though is that both app servers here are talking to the same primary database in this case an example SQL
Server uh primary uh uh database and uh and what happens is there synchronous replication going on in in the form of
uh what Microsoft call SQL Server mirroring and so this is mirroring to a secondary server and the idea is and and
there's a there's a third server for an N plus1 redundancy that's there observing the the transactions that
there's a failover event the idea is just that um the application will fail over and these two app servers will then
start talking to the SQL server on this side now uh if you're using the native SQL Server drivers that happens automatically uh you may have to put a
script there to detect the failover event and and make that happen but that that's how customers have been doing uh
this in the environment and that the same scenario Works beautifully with Oracle and Oracle Data Guard and so

this works really well in traditional data centers as well it's uh it's really just good practice to have some

Guard to another region and a few of the uh applications that that we've been working with so again these these are

Point objectives um you know how you design the back end of these systems I think the important thing to know is
that um you know it's it's it's very much about what the recovery time looks like if if you're okay with taking two
hours to recover from a disaster event then it's okay to ship data and trickle data overnight logs transaction logs
from one region to another and if something really bad happens you just start up the whole environment in another region and that may take an hour

that you know customers are taking our building blocks and they're they're putting them together to make an application and we control some of those
building blocks but then they're taking control of the the application the prime contractor or the agency has taking
control of of the final product and so there is a shared responsibility model and this is this is the big difference
and uh in the environment and so you we have we have responsibility for things that are in our control so the facilities everything from the concrete
up to the operating systems that are running in the environment uh the virtual infrastructure The Logical
separation that we have in the environment uh all of the virtual uh machines and the virtual infrastructure
but but customers are still responsible when I say customers I say this Loosely it can a partner um whoever's hosting the

configuring our security groups uh correctly um responsible for uh making
sure that they have um antivirus installed and and so a lot of the traditional security practices that
happen there um and so that's an important differentiation and so one of the things that we've spent a lot of time working

you'll see we we a pretty rich um collection of Partners um that we've developed over the last few years to

Solutions that really range uh all different areas but they have one in particular called uh deep security and
and deep security is a system that has modules for malware for IDs for audit
for firewalling that you can plug in and they run on individual server instances but they can be managed centrally and so

U called secure Cloud um and so in that uh solution um what they what the focus area is on
is Key Management so encryption very simple thing to do Key Management very difficult thing to do and so one of the
challenges in the cloud world is that you know on premise world you can plug a Hardware security module and HSM into a
server uh the keys are created there they live there but when you run things in a virtual world we don't have this
idea of of an HSM and so getting Keys delivered securely is is a challenge and so the these guys we've spent a lot of
time working on security protocols for secure delivery of keys into the environment there there actually two solutions that I'm very bullish on on

protect V we've done a lot of work with both both teams and and we're really happy with the progress um for both of
